items.title: Will this project new release future?
items.body:
Hi @dbader 

Thank you for the great project. I'm afraid to open this issue.

Although new issues are created often and many pull requests are open,
this project hasn't been released for more than 10 months
and @dbader has no activity since Aug, 2019.

Many people would find value and benefit from this tool. So, could you tell us about the future of this project?

items.title: Return Flask jsonify response of schedule.jobs
items.body:
I am currently using the Python Schedule library in a Flask app and would like to return a jsonify response of my schedule.jobs. Schedule.jobs returns a default list of all the jobs in my schedule. Schedule.jobs returns a list of class objects (a list of [schedule.Job objects](https://schedule.readthedocs.io/en/stable/_modules/schedule.html#Job)).

I'm aware that the Flask JSON library does not allow you to jsonify a list. I have tried json dumps but got the following error: TypeError: Object of type Job is not JSON serializable.

How can I return a jsonify response of my list of class objects? See below for code:
`
>>> import schedule
>>> import time

>>> def geeks():
...     print("Shaurya says Geeksforgeeks")
... 
>>> def good_luck():
...     print("Good luck!")
... 
>>> def work():
...     print("Study hard work harder")
... 
>>> schedule.every(5).seconds.do(geeks)
Every 5 seconds do geeks() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:12:41)
>>> schedule.every(10).seconds.do(work)
Every 10 seconds do work() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:07)
>>> schedule.every(15).seconds.do(good_luck)
Every 15 seconds do good_luck() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:25)
>>> schedule.jobs
[Every 5 seconds do geeks() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:12:41), Every 10 seconds do work() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:07), Every 15 seconds do good_luck() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:25)]


>>> print(type(schedule.jobs))
<class 'list'>

>>> print(type(schedule.jobs[0]))
<class 'schedule.Job'>

>>> print(schedule.jobs[0])
Every 5 seconds do geeks() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:12:41)

>>> schedule_list = []
>>> for items in schedule.jobs:
...     schedule_list.append(items)
... 
>>> schedule_list
[Every 5 seconds do geeks() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:12:41), Every 10 seconds do work() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:07), Every 15 seconds do good_luck() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 11:13:25)]

>>> print(type(schedule_list[0]))
<class 'schedule.Job'>

>>> print(json.dumps(schedule_list))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/linda/opt/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/json/__init__.py", line 231, in dumps
    return _default_encoder.encode(obj)
  File "/Users/linda/opt/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/json/encoder.py", line 199, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/Users/linda/opt/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/json/encoder.py", line 257, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/Users/linda/opt/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/json/encoder.py", line 179, in default
    raise TypeError(f'Object of type {o.__class__.__name__} '
TypeError: Object of type Job is not JSON serializable
`

I have also tried JSON pickle, however the encode results look different. I would like the return to be a jsonify string like this:

Every 5 seconds do geek() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 16:58:45)
Every 5 seconds do work() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 16:58:49)

However, I'm getting this:
`
>>> for item in schedule.jobs:
...     print(item)
... 
Every 5 seconds do geek() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 16:58:45)
Every 5 seconds do work() (last run: [never], next run: 2020-05-04 16:58:49)
>>> for item in schedule.jobs:
...     schedJSON = jsonpickle.encode(item, unpicklable=False)
...     sched.append(schedJSON)
... 
>>> sched
['{"at_time": null, "interval": 5, "job_func": {"__annotations__": {}, "__doc__": null, "__module__": "__main__", "__name__": "geek", "__qualname__": "geek", "__wrapped__": null}, "last_run": null, "latest": null, "next_run": "2020-05-04 16:58:45.669355", "period": null, "scheduler": {"jobs": [null, {"at_time": null, "interval": 5, "job_func": {"__annotations__": {}, "__doc__": null, "__module__": "__main__", "__name__": "work", "__qualname__": "work", "__wrapped__": null}, "last_run": null, "latest": null, "next_run": "2020-05-04 16:58:49.000268", "period": null, "scheduler": null, "start_day": null, "tags": [], "unit": "seconds"}]}, "start_day": null, "tags": [], "unit": "seconds"}', '{"at_time": null, "interval": 5, "job_func": {"__annotations__": {}, "__doc__": null, "__module__": "__main__", "__name__": "work", "__qualname__": "work", "__wrapped__": null}, "last_run": null, "latest": null, "next_run": "2020-05-04 16:58:49.000268", "period": null, "scheduler": {"jobs": [{"at_time": null, "interval": 5, "job_func": {"__annotations__": {}, "__doc__": null, "__module__": "__main__", "__name__": "geek", "__qualname__": "geek", "__wrapped__": null}, "last_run": null, "latest": null, "next_run": "2020-05-04 16:58:45.669355", "period": null, "scheduler": null, "start_day": null, "tags": [], "unit": "seconds"}, null]}, "start_day": null, "tags": [], "unit": "seconds"}']
`

items.title: Running Job between given times randomly
items.body:
First of all, thanks for the amazing library! I'm looking to run a task randomly between 10 am - 10 pm. So I've written the code below. It's obviously wrong as I was just trying to put everything together. 

Is there such a feature available? :) Thanks! 

```
def action():
    schedule.every(2).to(8).hours.do(run_threaded, xxx)
    schedule.every(3).to(4).hours.do(run_threaded, zzz)

schedule.every().day.at('10:00').to('22:00').do(run_threaded, action)

```

items.title: How Does Long Process Effect Schedule
items.body:
Hi everyone,
I'm trying to better understand how the schedule works. I have a schedule like the following.
```
schedule.every(60).to(80).minutes.do(longprocess)
```
`longprocess` usually takes ~20 minutes to finish. Will the program count down 60-80 minutes after `longprocess` finishes? Or does it count 60-80 minutes from when `longprocess` starts? Thanks in advance.

items.title: how can I cancel the jobs ?
items.body:
I have wrong with cancel cancel_job this is a demo:
```
import schedule
import time

def test(t):
    print t

schedule.every().second.do(test,"test1111 !!!")
schedule.every().second.do(test,"test2222 !!!")
schedule.every().second.do(test,"test3333 !!!")


while True:
    schedule.run_pending()
    for i in schedule.jobs:
        schedule.cancel_job(i)
    time.sleep(1)
```
In this demo schedule.jobs length is 3 but Only 2 loops.One of these jobs left uncancelled.
The code of cancel_job():
```
 try:
    self.jobs.remove(job)
except ValueError:
    pass
```

items.title: Assertions missing error messages

Sometimes the assertion errors can be vague. It would be an easy fix to save some time debugging.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39542938/51077016-42890380-166e-11e9-84a6-c27f8979885d.png)

items.title: scheduler does not account for job execution time
items.body:
It seems that schedule does not account for the time it takes the scheduled job to complete.  For example:

```
import schedule
from datetime import datetime
from time import sleep

def job(seconds):
    print(datetime.now().strftime('%H:%M:%S.%f'))
    sleep(seconds)

schedule.every(10).seconds.do(job, 2)
while True:
    schedule.run_pending()
```

This code example executes `job` every 12 seconds instead of every 10.  This is not noticeable if jobs are short - but in my case they may take several hours (delay is 1 day), so this is quite problematic.

items.title: Will you accept a PR that lets users schedule to the second?
items.body:
### Background
I'm working for a company that is trying to develop software to manage the electronic TV-screen-sized ad-billboards you see in malls.  The billboard software needs to be able to schedule various events throughout the day, with the events often needing to be scheduled to the second or possibly even tenth or hundredth of a second.  The CTO recommended using this `schedule` package to handle this.

### The problem
I've noticed that the `at()` function in this package does not allow users to schedule things to the second or millisecond, and I'm wondering if I can submit a PR that will add this functionality, or if there's some other package that I should consider instead.  For example, I've spent a few minutes looking at the Python built-in `sched` package and it seems like it may do what I need.  It seems like this `schedule` package is really meant more for cron-job-like tasks.

items.title: Dumb Q: What is time.sleep() doing?
items.body:
Hi,

I'm writing a function that gets run every 28 minutes as below:

```
import schedule
import time

def foo():
    print('do something')

schedule.every(28).minutes.do(foo)

while True:
    schedule.run_pending()
    time.sleep(1)
```

But I don't understand `time.sleep(1)` here. Do I need this here? I just want to make sure foo() gets called every 28 minutes. 

Also, how do I initialise the schedule, do I have to call it from somewhere? (This snippet will be in a Django project.)

Thank you!

items.title: Running a scheduled task if a condition is met within a while loop
items.body:
I want to run a scheduled task on the condition that variable=1.

So far, I've written:

    import schedule
    import time
    
    def job1():
      print("123")

    def job2():
      print("456")
    
    while True:
        from otherscript import variable
        if variable==1:
        	print("on")
        	schedule.every().day.at("06:05").do(job1) 
        	schedule.every(10).minutes.do(job2).tag('10mintasks')
        if variable==0:
        	print("off")
        	schedule.clear('10mintasks')

        schedule.run_pending()
        time.sleep(1)

On second thought, I think this might be a wrong way of writing the code, since if `schedule.every()` is in the while loop, then the scheduled task will occur more frequently than 10mins. I think everytime the loop occurs, a new 10mins task is created, causing many 10mins tasks to be generated over time. The `schedule.every()` might thus need to be outside the while loop. This is also reflected in the example in the documentation.


Thus, is there a way I can write conditions for the scheduled 10 mins task to run based on a variable that can change in a while loop?

```
schedule.cancel_job(job)
```

items.title: Scheduled tasks are not called anymore
items.body:
Everything was fine, but on the last week scheduling stopped working. I made some testing:
I have a script which defines few scheduled tasks. When running from command string this way: `python myscript.py` schedule work just fine. But when I run this script from another script: 
`newprocess="nohup python myscript.py"
os.system(newprocess)`
the scheduled tasks are not called there.
in myscript.py, schedule is performed in a separate thread:
`def scheduler_function():
    while 1:
        schedule.run_pending()
        time.sleep(1)

thread = Thread(target = scheduler_function, args = ())
thread.start()`

Can you please help me with this?

items.title: How to read schedule from config file?
items.body:
I need to read a list of jobs from configuration file in json format, which looks like:
```
{
  "jobs" : [
    { "id" : "job1", cron : "daily 11:30", "arg" : "this is an argument for job1" },
    { "id" : "job2", cron : "every 10 minutes", "arg" : 12.34 },
    ...
  ]
}
```
The `cron` field is just illustrative. Actually I would like to use crontab syntax which looks like:
```
schedule.add("* * * 30 *", worker_func)
```
but seems not supported yet. Any similar approach?

items.title: How do I schedule a monthly cron-like trigger?
items.body:
I am currently using Python 2.7 with the schedule module to trigger a python function call every hour and every day at GMT and far it is working great.

```
schedule.every().hour.do(lambda: run_db_aggregation(url_list, 'hourly'))
schedule.every().day.at("12:00").do(lambda: run_db_aggregation(url_list, 'daily'))
```

The problem is I am _not_ able to use any monthly cron modules using the existing support (or maybe I don't know yet). I tried using the days option, but I can;t pre-load it for 30 days as they vary every month and also weeks cannot be set to 4  (or may be it could be?)

Also one major problem is I am running this script as a Linux systemd service, so if I add the 4 week schedule run and do a restart service anytime after it is scheduled, the entire job is offset by the new time (current weeks passed + new 4 weeks (due to application restart)).

How do I get about fixing this issue? Is there a monthly cron module which I can load so that I need not worry about service restarts, so that it fires at certain day of the month every time?

items.title: pip install shedule does not work on rhel
it works fine with scrapy module
items.body:
this module works fine with scrapy module, but do not using buitin `scrapy.cmdline`

```py
def crawl_work():
    cmdline.execute('scrapy crawl my_spider'.split())
if __name__=='__main__':
    schedule.every(1).minutes.do(crawl_work)
    while True:
            schedule.run_pending()
            time.sleep(1)
```
run only once, the program will exited.

change the scrapy.cmdline to subprocess
```py
def crawl_work():
    subprocess.Popen('scrapy crawl my_spider')
```
it works very well

items.title: How to stop the scheduled Job

items.title: Differing object instance ID's
items.body:
Here is a sample line of code:

schedule.every().day.at(circuitDriver.startString).do(run_threaded,circuitDriver.start)

There are 8 instances of circuitDriver.  Each is populated with unique hardware address to actuate a relay.   When the scheduler calls the job it calls it with an instance that is not equal to the one the scheduler was created with thus the circuit actuation fails because the HW relay address is not set/invalid.  

How do I make the scheduler use the instance I initiated it with?

items.title: support CRON expression
items.body:
I would be interesting to create a job from a [cron expression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron#CRON_expression).

For exemple, I want to schedule a job every day a 7 I would use something like
`schedule.cronline("0 7 * * *").do(job)`

Here the same example for weekday at 8:30
`schedule.cronline("30 8 * * 1-5").do(job)`

It is something implemented in [python-crontab ](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-crontab)lib. See `job.setall(string)`

Got this question via email, posting it here for reference:

> Is there a way to allow running the scheduled job immediately then every(x)?
>
> Something like this:
>
> schedule.every(10).minutes.do(start=datetime.now(), job)

items.title: Migrating over community-driven project
items.body:
To everyone interested,
in this last weeks I tried to contact the author of the library in order to let the project move on again.
This was due to the fact that the author itself hasn't accepted a single PR or committed a line from the 6th of march of this year, and the code itself began to age (no CI tools integration with 3.4/3.5, to cite one). Anyhow the contact attempt failed, and I never got a feedback.
What I thought now, after a [brief discussion](https://github.com/dbader/schedule/pull/102) with @laubed was that maybe the project could continue in another repository, possibly keeping the fork with the original project and possibly having more than one contributor in order to ensure that any author defections will never let the project lag behind.

I'm surely still hoping that the author will return, and if he will we also pull the forked version over his. 
Please, tell me if you see any other solution than this, otherwise we'll organize a place for discussing more deeply the topic.

items.title: How Can I kill/stop the Schedule
Add api to start scheduler in a separate Thread
items.body:
I've noticed common pattern across my services with `schedule` where I use the following block

``` python
while True:
    schedule.run_pending()
    time.sleep(1)
```

as

``` python

....
def spawn():
    while True:
        schedule.run_pending()
        time.sleep(1)

if __name__ == '__main__':
   Thread(target=spawn).start()
   ....
```

to schedule some tasks but continue running code in the main thread. I think will be really useful to  have `spawn` method in the library

items.title: Job not running
items.body:
There is one task out of several that is not running or getting scheduled for its next run incorrectly.
The task 'catalog_export' typically runs for 90-120 minutes so the start is occurs on one day at it finishes on the next day. We run it on the staging environment at 3am and it has never failed to run correctly, so I am wondering if the start date being different from the end date could be a factor. 

Before enabling schedule logging it failed twice. The pattern was that it ran successfully on the initial run, failed to run on the next night, ran sucessfully on the following (third) night, and then failed to run again on the fourth night.

The code says:
`schedule.every().day.at("23:25").do(catalog_export)
`
And it appears in the log:

> 2016-04-11 23:25:00,334 = schedule - INFO - Running job Every 1 day at 23:25:00 do catalog_export() (last run: [never], next run: 2016-04-11 23:25:00)

Here is one that worked without incident and was scheduled before catalog_export and ran the next day without incident.

> 2016-04-11 23:15:00,397 = schedule - INFO - Running job Every 1 day at 23:15:00 do customerAlias_load() (last run: [never], next run: 2016-04-11 23:15:00)
> 
> 2016-04-12 23:15:00,048 = schedule - INFO - Running job Every 1 day at 23:15:00 do customerAlias_load() (last run: 2016-04-11 23:16:55, next run: 2016-04-12 23:15:00)

But there is nothing in the log for catalog_export on 2016-04-12, 23:25 is just silent.

2016-04-12 23:16:51,927 = cat2es.customerAlias_load - INFO - finished at: 23:16:51 
2016-04-12 23:57:24,667 = schedule - INFO - Running job Every 60 minutes do heartbeat() (last run: 2016-04-12 22:57:24, next run: 2016-04-12 23:57:24)

There are two logs attached.
In the log for 20160411:
between lines 22-23: catalog_export fails to run
line 34: schedule log enabled
line 96: catalog_export starts, and is rescheduled

in the log for 20160412:
between lines 20-31: catalog_export fails to run

[cat2es_20160412_log.txt](https://github.com/dbader/schedule/files/219101/cat2es_20160412_log.txt)
[cat2es_20160411_log.txt](https://github.com/dbader/schedule/files/219102/cat2es_20160411_log.txt)

items.title: How distributed can schedule become?
items.body:
I came across this project on HN and am putting together my mental team of projects for a software literate company - and wanted to understand a bit more.

Cron suffers from being fixed to one machine - whereas a company or organisation almost be default has more than one server and wants to load balance in some form

The first part (distributed job definitions) seems simple - text files can be as distributed as you like and brought together

The next stage is after the jobs have been scheduled, to have them sent out and run on more than one server - to have a grid, treat it as a grid and scheduler for it 

How amenable is the schedule package to that step (or is it already there and I can stop worrying!)

items.title: Scheduler doesn't execute function within class (is it because it's not a first-class function)?
TypeError 'Job' object is not callable when running schedule within class
items.body:
Hi,

I need help with this code snippet. Below, I'm instantiating a schedule object within a class.
And from within the class I'm running my loop which I hope to run the scheduled job. It seems the "at" method won't accept the job I give it throwing a TypeError. Whereas running it every minute works fine.
In both cases assert statement does not fire. Can someone provide insight?

Thanks,
Dennis

``` python
import schedule
import time

class TestSchedule():

    def __init__(self):
        self.schedule = schedule

    def setup(self):
        ### WORKS ###
        # self.schedule.every(1).minutes.do(self.job)
        assert callable(self.job)
        ### DOESN'T WORK ###
        self.schedule.every().day().at("7:54").do(self.job)

    def job(self):
        print 'Job start at {0}'.format(time.strftime('%H:%M'))

    def loop(self):
        while 1:
            self.schedule.run_pending()
            print 'Sleeping for 10 sec'
            time.sleep(10)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    ts = TestSchedule()
    ts.setup()
    print 'Start schedule at {0}'.format(time.strftime('%H:%M'))
    ts.loop()

```

items.title: schedule with flask microframework
items.body:
Hi! how can i use schedule as a cron job with flask microframework? This is the answer i found on stackoverflow

``` python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

"""
This script is a simple example you can use to schedule task with flask 
microframework and schedule (https://github.com/dbader/schedule).
I've found it on on stackoverflow!
"""

import time
import schedule

from flask import Flask, request
from threading import Thread

app = Flask(__name__)

start_time = time.time()

def run_every_10_seconds():
    print("Running periodic task!")
    print "Elapsed time: " + str(time.time() - start_time)

def run_schedule():
    while 1:
        schedule.run_pending()
        time.sleep(1)   

@app.route('/', methods=['GET'])
def index():
    return '<html>test</html>'

if __name__ == '__main__':
    schedule.every(10).seconds.do(run_every_10_seconds)
    t = Thread(target=run_schedule)
    t.start()
    print "Start time: " + str(start_time)
    app.run(debug=True, host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, use_reloader=False)
```

items.title: Wrong next_run calculation
items.body:
I believe this line

https://github.com/dbader/schedule/blob/master/schedule/__init__.py#L325

is missing an 

```
and self.interval == 1
```

because when you set for example:

```
scheduler.every(2).days.at('12:00').do(job)
```

executing it after 12:00 will schedule next_run for the next 2 days, and executing it before 12:00 will schedule to the next day, breaking the 2-day rule

to see it happen just change 

```
with mock_datetime(2010, 1, 6, 13, 16):
```

to

```
with mock_datetime(2010, 1, 6, 10, 16):
```

here: https://github.com/dbader/schedule/blob/master/test_schedule.py#L192
